content:
Well, the beta isn't as reliable as the release version, but you've used it for a long time. I feel you would be safer to stick with the release version, but as long as you do frequent (i.e., weekly) backups, it doesn't matter. I back up weekly and any problems are quickly behind me. You can revert to the release by going to thunderbird.net and downloading and installing over the top of the beta. Then, there may be a compatibilities.ini file in the profile to delete to avoid the message that the release is not compatible. BUT, my big suggestion is to do backups. To do that, I suggest these steps: - exit thunderbird - copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to external media

And I was walking before you were born...  :)
creator: davidsk

content:
Hiervoor is het nodig een voorkeur weer in te schakelen.

Ga hiervoor naar het menu > Instellingen. Zoek naar config en klik op de knop Configuratie-editor. Bevestig dat u voorzichtig zult zijn. Typ vervolgens in het veld Voorkeursnaam zoeken de volgende voorkeur: mail.warn_on_delete_from_trash. Klik naast deze voorkeur op de knop Wisselen om de voorkeur om te schakelen. Sla de wijziging op en sluit de Configuratie-editor. Hierna zou er weer gevraagd moeten worden of het bericht moet worden verwijderd.

content:
@David, just remember that there will be changes to the profile data. Whatever was changed will represent data loss to the relevant user.

There is no official way of "going back" I suggest folk be referred to the feedback site to vent whatever feeling they have about that decision, because it as a consciously made decision in the Thunderbird V68 time frame.

Likewise the choice to opt out of upgrades was similarly removed. That situation will not resolve unless Thunderbird users make their feelings about lack of choice known.

content: - click hamburger (three stacked lines) icon in upper right - click addons&themes - click textmarker in search window - install - after install, click the icon of a wrench in the description field and set to your preferences. l - then, whenever you click the 'new message' button, you will see the textmarker icon on upper toolbar for use. It appears whether you're composing in HTML or plain text, but only works with HTML message.

content: The 'again' appears beside the last 'move' that you did. that is, if you move message X to trash and later click another message to move somewhere, thunderbird remembers the last move that you did and includes that in context menu. the intent is to minimize user mouse clicks.

content:
It will help if you tell us whether your email account is POP (messages kept on PC), or IMAP (messages kept on server). My guess is IMAP, since you indicated that you have access to messages on both phone and PC Also, from menu bar, click help>about and share the version of Thunderbird that you are using.

I know nothing of Plusnet, but I have had good success with an email account at Gmail (free), one at Outlook (free), and one with gmx (also free), and one at Fastmail (fee), and there are others. All of those work with Thunderbird the same way, but that is something for you to make the decision on. If you switch, my suggestion is set up the new account at least a month or more before leaving Plusnet to ensure that you retain email access throughout, as you may have many people to notify of the switch.

We can advise on possibly upgrading your Thunderbird after you share the version in use. You mentioned the limited storage of Thunderbird. Actually, Thunderbird has no limits itself, but uses whatever resources the user provides.

So, next steps: you need to decide on a new email address if that is your desire. You will need to set on the PC and your phone. If you have difficulties, you can post here for help in that. I encourage that to be a new post, not a follow on from this one. When you want to exit Plusnet and save the messages, please make that another separate post to ensure you get assistance on that one topic. Finally, after you tell us which version you use, we can advise on the upgrade from this post.

So, at this time, the ball is in your court. Let us know.
creator: davidsk

content: You will need to provide much more information before anyone can respond.

content:
1) http://kb.mozillazine.org/Icons_-_Thunderbird_2 The arrow indicates the message was replied. Pointing to the right indicates it was forwarded.

2) The separator between the message list and the message pane can be moved by click and drag. Click the 3-bar menu icon, upper right, to adjust Font Size for the list.

3) Set display fonts in Settings/General/Language & Appearance, Advanced, with Fonts for: Latin and repeat with Fonts for: Other Writing Systems. Sizes are in pixels. Uncheck 'Allow messages...'.

content:
This is a P.S. to the Audio issue.

I had found the audio setting, and entered a selection.

A short time ago, I began hearing the selection (which includes several Blue Jay calls). It would stop for a couple of minutes, then repeat, and kept repeating.

I thought that I've been getting the reminder popups, that it might be Thunderbird audio catching up with the popups. It was both annoying and humorous.

I opened Task Manager and saw a couple of items flickering when the sound was heard. I "stopped" them, and for awhile it was quiet. Then I began hearing them again.

Instead of using Task Manager this time. I unchecked the audio option. It's been quiet since. 

(Insert laughing smiley.)

content:
Thanks! I think that solved the problem. One more question... I notice that sending messages seems a lot slower lately. Do you know of any reason for that?

I appreciate your prompt responses!
creator: carlamacc2

content:
Sending speed can be degraded if you have an antivirus scanning outgoing mail, e.g. Avast Mail Shield. The general recommendation is to exclude the TB profile folder from AV scanning and to disable scanning of secure (SSL) connections, leaving the real-time background scanner in place.

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Antivirus_software
creator: sfhowes

content:
I don't think that's the problem, but I will read the link more carefully. Thanks.

Can the volume of emails in the inbox, or in folders cause outgoing mail, to be slower?
creator: carlamacc2

content:
Ideally, you want to keep the number of messages as small as possible, especially in Inbox, but it probably takes tens of thousands before performance is affected, barring other factors like AV, network performance etc. The All Mail folder can get quite large, but most users unsubscribe it since it's redundant.

If you run Windows in safe mode, that will test the effect of startup apps like AV, since they are bypassed in safe mode.
creator: sfhowes

content:
That is very helpful to know. My All Mail folder has almost 25K messages. On more than one occasion I have found this folder very helpful when something goes missing for some reason, so I'm hesitant to unsubscribe to it.

There is also another folder called "Important". It's also quite large. I assume these are also included in the "All Mail" folder? If so, perhaps I could unsubscribe to that folder to cut down the number of emails.

What are the criteria to make it go into "Important"? Is there any reason why I shouldn't unsubscribe to this folder instead of the All Mail folder?
creator: carlamacc2

content:
In gmail webmail settings, Inbox, Importance markers, it's stated"

"Gmail analyzes your new incoming messages to predict what's important, considering things like how you've treated similar messages in the past, how directly the message is addressed to you, and many other factors."

All received and sent messages are in All Mail, so I would think that includes the Important folder, unless you choose 'No markers'. In my setup, only Inbox, Sent Mail, Spam and Trash are subscribed. If I need to access All Mail, I do so in webmail.

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Gmail
creator: sfhowes

content:
Thanks! It looks like I have some reading to do.

I appreciate your information and prompt responses!
creator: carlamacc2
